title: Conference Presentations
text: Welcome to our collection of conference presentations focusing on educational technology and development tools. These presentations cover various aspects of modern software development, automated testing, and educational technology implementation.

title: Conference Presentations
text:
Available Presentations

Automated and Configurable Programming Project Checking with Chasten

Learn about automated project checking and configuration
Understand how to implement efficient project validation
Explore best practices for automated testing

Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions

Master GitHub workflow integration
Set up GitHub Classroom for educational purposes
Implement automated workflows with GitHub Actions

ExecExam: A Tool to Facilitate Effective Executable Examinations in Python

Discover tools for creating executable examinations
Learn about Python-based testing frameworks
Implement effective examination strategies

Building and Deploying Course Websites with Python, Quarto, and Mkdocs

Create modern course websites
Implement documentation with Mkdocs
Deploy and maintain educational content

title: Conference Presentations
text:
Getting Started
Each presentation is available in the slides section. You can navigate through the presentations using the navigation menu above. Each presentation includes:

Detailed slides with code examples
Implementation guides
Best practices and recommendations
Additional resources and references

title: Conference Presentations
text:
Contributing
These presentations are open source and available for educational purposes. Feel free to use and modify them according to your needs. If you find any issues or have suggestions for improvements, please contribute through our GitHub repository.

title: Automated and Configurable Programming Project Checking with Chasten
section: The Problem with Traditional Static Analysis
text:
The Problem with Traditional Static Analysis
Regular expression (regex) ‚â† code understanding

Fails on structural nuance
Hard to maintain across formatting/styles

title: Automated and Configurable Programming Project Checking with Chasten
section: The Problem with Traditional Static Analysis
text:
The Problem with Traditional Static Analysis
AST tools are powerful but complex

Require managing node types
Difficult to prototype new rules

title: Automated and Configurable Programming Project Checking with Chasten
text:
Chasten
A Python program that uses XPATH expressions to find patterns in the abstract syntax tree (AST) of a Python program

title: Automated and Configurable Programming Project Checking with Chasten
text:
What is an AST?
Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) = structured representation of code
x = 1 + 2
Assign
 ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Name(x)
 ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ BinOp(+)
      ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Constant(1)
      ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Constant(2)

title: Automated and Configurable Programming Project Checking with Chasten
text:
Why XPATH?

‚úÖ Perfect for navigating ASTs
‚úÖ Easy to write and understand

/FunctionDef/body//If[ancestor::If and not(parent::orelse)]
‚Äì> Matches function with double nested if

title: Automated and Configurable Programming Project Checking with Chasten
text:
Features

‚ú® Easy-to-configure, automated analysis of a Python program‚Äôs abstract syntax tree
üìÉ Flexible and easy-to-use YAML-based configuration file for describing analyses and checks
üöÄ Configurable saving of analysis results in the JSON, CSV, or SQLite formats
üåÑ Interactive results analysis through the use of a locally running datasette server

title: Automated and Configurable Programming Project Checking with Chasten

title: Automated and Configurable Programming Project Checking with Chasten
text: Chasten Workflow

title: Automated and Configurable Programming Project Checking with Chasten
text:
Key Takeaways

‚úÖ Declarative rule-writing with XPath
Easily define grading criteria and static analysis checks ‚Äî no need to write Python plugins.
üß† Teachable insights into code structure
Helps students understand Abstract Syntax Trees (ASTs) and how code is interpreted structurally.
üìä Structured, explorable outputs
Export results to SQLite and use Datasette to visualize errors, coverage, and student patterns.
üß™ Supports research and pedagogy
Useful for analyzing coding behavior at scale, detecting common anti-patterns in student code.
üìö Integrates into grading pipelines
Run Chasten on student submissions to check for required docstrings, type hints, nested logic, etc.

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
The Challenge of Programming Assignments

Distribution of starter code
Collection of submissions
Providing automated feedback
Managing final assessment
Coordinating all these tasks efficiently

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Traditional Assignment Workflow Challenges

Email submission creates version chaos
Manual testing is time-consuming and error-prone
Limited visibility into student progress
Feedback is often delayed and disconnected from code

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
section: Enter GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Enter GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
A complete ecosystem for programming education that:

Leverages industry-standard tools
Promotes good development practices
Automates tedious tasks
Provides immediate feedback
Creates a portfolio for students

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Benefits for Students

Learn professional version control practices
Get immediate feedback on their code
Clear indication of what to complete (TODOs)
Work in a real development environment
Build a portfolio of completed projects
Prepare for collaborative development

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Benefits for Instructors

Automated distribution of assignments
Centralized submission collection
Automated testing and grading assistance
Clear visibility into student progress
Consistent environment for all students
Rich feedback options (issues, PRs, comments)

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Getting Started: The Workflow

Create solution repository with tests
Create starter repository with TODOs
Set up GitHub Classroom
Create and distribute assignments
Monitor student progress
Provide feedback through GitHub
Assess completed work

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Step 1: Creating the Solution Repository
# Create new repository with complete solution
git init solution-repo
cd solution-repo
# Add your complete solution code

Include a comprehensive test suite with pytest
Set up linting with flake8/pylint
Create a GitHub Actions workflow
Ensure all tests pass with your solution

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Solution Repository Structure
solution-repo/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ solution.py
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tests/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ test_solution.py
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .github/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ workflows/
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ python-checks.yml
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ requirements.txt
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
GitHub Actions Workflow Example
name: Python Checks

on: [push]

jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v3
    - name: Set up Python
      uses: actions/setup-python@v4
      with:
        python-version: '3.10'
    - name: Install dependencies
      run: |
        python -m pip install --upgrade pip
        pip install pytest flake8
        if [ -f requirements.txt ]; then pip install -r requirements.txt; fi
    - name: Lint with flake8
      run: flake8 src tests
    - name: Test with pytest
      run: pytest

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
section: Step 2: Implementation Ablation - Creating the Starter
text:
Step 2: Implementation Ablation - Creating the Starter
What is implementation ablation?

Systematically remove implementation details from your solution
Replace with well-documented TODOs
Leave structure intact for students to complete
Keep tests to guide students

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Example of Implementation Ablation
Starter code:
def calculate_grade(scores):
    # TODO: Calculate the average score
    # Hint: You'll need to find the sum and divide by the count
    
    # TODO: Determine the letter grade based on the average
    # A: 90+, B: 80-89, C: 70-79, D: 60-69, F: below 60
    
    return None  # Replace with your implementation

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Step 3: Setting Up GitHub Classroom

Create a GitHub organization for your class
Authorize GitHub Classroom
Create a new classroom linked to your organization
Invite teaching assistants as organization admins

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Step 4: Creating an Assignment

Select ‚ÄúNew Assignment‚Äù in GitHub Classroom
Choose individual or group assignment
Name your assignment
Set deadline and visibility options
Import your starter repository
Enable automated testing

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Step 5: Distributing the Assignment

Generate invitation link
Share with students
Students click link and accept assignment
GitHub automatically creates private student repositories
Students clone locally and start working

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Student Experience

Accept assignment through unique link
Repository created with starter code
Clone repository locally
Complete TODOs guided by tests
Push changes to GitHub
Get immediate feedback from GitHub Actions

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Automated Feedback with GitHub Actions

Tests run automatically on every push
Students see red ‚ùå or green ‚úÖ status checks
Detailed feedback in Actions tab
Testing failures highlight what‚Äôs still incomplete

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Comprehensive Feedback Options
GitHub provides multiple feedback channels:

In-line comments on specific code lines
Issue creation for general feedback
Pull request reviews for detailed assessment
Automated checks for immediate technical feedback

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Example: Issue-Based Feedback

## Algorithm Efficiency

Your solution works but uses O(n¬≤) time complexity when 
an O(n) solution is possible. Consider using a hash map 
instead of nested loops.

## Code Structure

Great job breaking down the problem into functions!
Your solution is well-organized and easy to follow.

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Optional: Integrating with External Tools
GitHub Actions can integrate with:

Pytest for test coverage
Flake8/Pylint for style checking
Chasten for AST-based pattern checking
Custom grading tool such as ExecExam
And many more!

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Example: Integration with Chasten
- name: Check with Chasten
  run: |
    pip install chasten
    chasten check --config .chasten.yml src/

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Practical Tips from Experience

Start with simple assignments to build familiarity
Create clear README files with setup instructions
Include CI badges in README to show test status
Use descriptive commit messages for teaching moments
Consider a practice assignment for GitHub onboarding

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Common Challenges and Solutions



Challenges
Solutions




Git confusion
Provide cheat sheet and office hours


Merge conflicts
Teach basic conflict resolution


Test failures
Make test output student-friendly


Missing setup
Include detailed environment setup


Privacy concerns
Use private repositories

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Limitations to Be Aware Of

Learning curve for Git and GitHub
Setup time for first assignments
Need for internet access
Managing organization permissions

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Key Takeaways

GitHub Classroom creates realistic development workflows
Automated feedback saves instructor time
Students learn industry-standard tools and practices
Implementation ablation guides student learning
Comprehensive feedback through multiple channels

title: Up and Running with GitHub, GitHub Classroom, and GitHub Actions
text:
Questions?
Thank you for your attention!
